Dialogue: I don't accept the idea that he knows who his letter writer is, Jane. Because I don't accept the idea that there was a big bad wolf who saw Marty in his wheelchair.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why hasn't he picked up the phone and told Constable Haller that someone is sending him poison-pen letters?

Dialogue: I'll bet you a quarter that eyewash stuff was nonprescription. And I'll bet you another quarter he hasn't said anything to Mr. Haller.

Speaker: uncle al
Dialogue: Marty, do you see your suspect?

Dialogue: Do you really think that a man who took a rocket in the eye three nights ago could be out mowing his lawn? He'd either be in the hospital... or dead.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I didn't shoot him when he was a man. I shot him when he was-

Dialogue: When he was a werewolf. Yes. Right. Jesus. Jane, you don't really believe this madness, do you?

Dialogue: No- I guess I'll go home.

Dialogue: Yeah... seeya.

Dialogue: I ran out of gas.

Dialogue: I told you!

Dialogue: Shut up, Marty.

Dialogue: Uncle Al, if you don't tell me-

Dialogue: No... but I found some blood, smeared on a tree trunk in that grove.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: There! You see!

Speaker: uncle al
Dialogue: It could have been anything, Marty.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What about Father Lowe chasing me in his car and trying to run me down? You don't think that was a dream, do you?

Dialogue: No.

Dialogue: Lowe's car-?

Dialogue: Blue. This blue.

Dialogue: Jesus.

Dialogue: I know. I could have edited out all of the completely crazy stuff, but I thought you deserved to hear it with the bark on.

Dialogue: I appreciate that. Now, the next question: Do you believe any of this? You do, don't you?

Dialogue: Let's just say I believe Lester Lowe should be checked out.

Dialogue: That can be arranged.

Dialogue: I saw what I saw.

Dialogue: Don't tell me what I have to do and what I don't, booger-brains.

Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe he doesn't know, either.

Dialogue: I think he's going to come for me. Not just because I know who he is, but because I hurt him. Only I don't think he'll try again as Lowe.

Dialogue: Will you do it?

Dialogue: Please, Uncle Al.

Dialogue: Will you?

Dialogue: We won't!

Dialogue: I will- be good, kids.

Dialogue: Can I tell you kids something?

Dialogue: Sure, Uncle Al.

Dialogue: Yeah? Really?

Dialogue: Yeah. Really. The bitch of it is, we still are. Learn from your elders, dearies.

Dialogue: The moon's not down yet...

Dialogue: Then I'd have to kick your ass, dear boy.  Go on, now.
